title: First Occupation License: Why It Matters for New Builds
excerpt: Learn about the licencia de primera ocupación (LPO), why it's essential for new properties, how it differs from cédula de habitabilidad, and what happens if your builder delays obtaining it.
author: New Build Homes Costa Blanca

content.quickAnswer: The licencia de primera ocupación (LPO) is the final municipal authorization that declares a newly constructed property is legally habitable and complies with building codes. Without it, you cannot register your deed, connect utilities officially, or obtain a mortgage release—making it absolutely essential for any new build purchase.
content.intro: In the journey from off-plan purchase to occupancy, the first occupation license (licencia de primera ocupación, commonly abbreviated as LPO) represents the final critical milestone. This municipal authorization confirms that your newly completed property meets all building code, safety, and habitability standards and can legally be occupied. For buyers on the Costa Blanca—from the bustling developments in Torrevieja to the quieter hillside villas in Javea or Calpe—understanding the LPO is crucial. This document is distinct from the building license (licencia de obras) and from the cédula de habitabilidad (certificate of habitability), and confusion between these can cost you months of delays. This guide explains what the LPO is, why it matters for your ownership rights, how it differs from related documents, the typical timeline to obtain it, what happens when it is delayed, and how to ensure your builder obtains it before you complete your purchase.

sections.title: What Is the First Occupation License (Licencia de Primera Ocupación)?

subsections.heading: Definition and Legal Significance
subsections.content: The licencia de primera ocupación (LPO) is an official authorization issued by the town hall (ayuntamiento) that permits the first human occupation of a newly constructed building. It is issued only after the building has been completed, inspected, and certified as compliant with all applicable building codes, safety standards, habitability requirements, and the original building license terms. The LPO is distinct from building permission or permits for construction—it is specifically about habitability and legal occupancy. In Spain's administrative framework, no building can legally be occupied for residential purposes without an LPO. This is not a minor formality; it is a condition precedent to numerous other essential rights: registering the property deed, connecting utilities, obtaining insurance, claiming the building in a will, and most critically, completing your mortgage transaction. The LPO is issued by the competent municipal authority—typically the Servicio de Licencias y Disciplina Urbanística (Licensing and Urban Compliance Service) at the town hall.

subsections.heading: Who Issues the LPO and Who Applies
subsections.content: The municipality's town hall issues the LPO after confirming the property is ready for occupancy. The application is made by the developer or builder, not by the buyer. In the developer's role as the legal constructor, they are responsible for ensuring all construction is complete and compliant, then submitting the LPO application with evidence of completion and inspection reports. This places responsibility firmly on the developer—they must apply within a defined period after construction completion or face penalties and fines. The developer cannot transfer this responsibility to you as a buyer; it remains their legal obligation. However, from a practical standpoint, buyers should monitor whether the developer is pursuing the LPO promptly, as delays directly affect your ability to take possession. Your purchase contract should explicitly state when the developer will apply for and obtain the LPO, typically within 3–6 months of substantial completion.

subsections.heading: The Application Process
subsections.content: The LPO application process involves several steps. First, the developer submits a request to the town hall, usually accompanied by: (1) the completion certificate (acta de finalización de obra) proving construction is finished; (2) inspection reports from the final municipal inspection; (3) certificates from mechanical and safety inspectors confirming electrical, plumbing, and fire safety systems are operational; (4) proof of payment of cesiones (infrastructure contributions); (5) proof that any required modifications or remedial work identified during inspections has been completed; and (6) proof of compliance with environmental and accessibility requirements. The town hall then conducts a final on-site inspection to verify that the property matches the building license specifications and all utilities and safety systems are functional. If everything is approved, the LPO is issued within 1–4 weeks. If deficiencies are found, the developer must remedy them and resubmit. In well-functioning municipalities on the Costa Blanca, such as Torrevieja or Benidorm, the process typically takes 1–3 months from application to issuance. In slower or more bureaucratic municipalities, it can extend to 4–6 months.

sections.title: LPO vs. Cédula de Habitabilidad: Understanding the Difference

subsections.heading: What Is the Cédula de Habitabilidad?
subsections.content: The cédula de habitabilidad is a certificate of habitability issued by the regional government (Conselleria de Vivienda, in the case of the Valencian Community where most of the Costa Blanca is located). It certifies that the property meets minimum living standards: adequate size, ventilation, light, and utilities. For new buildings, a cédula de habitabilidad is issued automatically upon completion of the LPO—the LPO is the gateway to it. For older properties being renovated or resold, a cédula must be obtained or renewed separately; it is required for property sale transfers. The cédula costs approximately €30–€60 and is valid indefinitely (though it must be transferred when the property is sold). Many people conflate the LPO and cédula de habitabilidad, thinking they are the same thing, but they are distinct: the LPO is the municipal authorization to occupy; the cédula is the regional certificate of habitability standards.

subsections.heading: Why You Need Both for a New Build
subsections.content: For a new property on the Costa Blanca, the sequence is: (1) Building license (licencia de obras) is issued, permitting construction; (2) Construction is completed and inspected; (3) Completion certificate (acta de finalización) is issued; (4) LPO is applied for and issued by the town hall; (5) Cédula de habitabilidad is issued by the regional government. You need both the LPO and cédula de habitabilidad before you can register the property deed at the Property Registry and secure all utilities. Some mistakenly believe they need only the cédula, but without the LPO, the municipality has not authorized occupancy, and the deed cannot be registered. Your purchase contract should stipulate that the developer will obtain both documents before you complete the final payment. Banks typically will not release final mortgage tranches until the Property Registry confirms the deed is registered, which requires both documents.

subsections.heading: Which Takes Precedence?
subsections.content: The LPO takes legal precedence. Once the LPO is issued by the town hall, the property is authorized for occupancy under municipal law. The cédula de habitabilidad follows as a regional confirmation of habitability standards. In practice, delays obtaining the cédula are rare—once the LPO is issued, the cédula is processed quickly, often within 2–4 weeks. The bottleneck is typically the LPO, which depends on the developer's diligence in applying and on the municipality's inspection and administrative workload. If you are completing your purchase and the LPO has been issued but the cédula is pending, your lawyer can typically complete the Property Registry transaction with the LPO in hand, and the cédula is registered immediately afterward.

sections.title: Why You Need the LPO: Critical Legal and Practical Reasons

subsections.heading: Prerequisite for Property Registration (Registro de la Propiedad)
subsections.content: The Property Registry (Registro de la Propiedad) will not register the deed to your property without an LPO. The LPO is your proof that the property legally exists and can be occupied—without it, the Registry treats the deed application as premature. You cannot become the legal owner recorded in the Registry without the LPO; you remain the owner only under contract. This is why purchasing off-plan carries risk—you sign a contract, but you don't legally own the property until the deed is registered, which requires the LPO. Some builders attempt to convince buyers to complete payments before the LPO is ready, promising to complete the registration later. Reject this arrangement. Always insist that the final payment is withheld until the deed is registered at the Property Registry, which cannot occur without the LPO. This is your leverage to ensure the developer obtains the LPO.

subsections.heading: Essential for Utilities Connection
subsections.content: Water companies, electricity providers, and gas companies will not officially connect utilities to a property without an LPO (and increasingly, proof of Property Registry registration). They require proof that the building is legally authorized for occupancy. Without official utility connections, you cannot: obtain a formal supply contract with the utility company, access emergency services, obtain homeowner's insurance, or refinance the mortgage. Some properties function temporarily with informal utility connections—the developer illegally taps into municipal water or electricity—but these are precarious and subject to disconnection and fines if discovered. For your security and legal status, utilities must be formally connected, which requires the LPO. This is especially important on the Costa Blanca, where summer peak demand puts pressure on water supplies and municipalities actively enforce compliance.

subsections.heading: Required for Mortgage Release and Bank Completion
subsections.content: When you obtain a mortgage to purchase a new build, the bank disburses funds in tranches (typically 30% on signing, 40% during construction, 30% on completion). The bank will not release the final 30% until the LPO is obtained and the deed is registered in your name at the Property Registry. This final disbursement is essential for you to complete the purchase and for the builder to receive final payment. If the builder delays the LPO, they do not receive final payment—this is a powerful incentive for them to obtain it promptly. However, some builders attempt to pressure buyers to allow them to complete funds release without the LPO by claiming financial difficulty. Refuse this. Your legal protection is more important than the builder's cash flow. Your mortgage agreement stipulates that funds are released upon conditions being met; those conditions exist to protect you.

subsections.heading: Insurance and Liability Protection
subsections.content: Insurance companies will not issue a homeowner's insurance policy (póliza de seguros) for a property without an LPO. Insurance companies view properties without the LPO as unfinished or legally questionable and decline coverage. Without insurance, you have no protection against fire, theft, or liability claims. This is a significant vulnerability. Additionally, during the period between completing your purchase and receiving the LPO, there is ambiguity about who is liable for damage or accidents at the property. Technically, the builder remains responsible as the legal constructor until the LPO is issued. Once the LPO is issued and the deed is registered, that liability fully transfers to you. This is another reason to insist the developer obtain the LPO before you complete final payment—to clarify liability.

subsections.heading: Inheritance and Estate Planning
subsections.content: If you wish to will your Spanish property to family members, the property must be registered in your name at the Property Registry. This requires the LPO. Without it, your property cannot be legally included in a Spanish will and cannot be formally transferred to your heirs. This is particularly important for buyers purchasing in Spain as an investment for future family use or as inheritance. Additionally, under Spanish succession law, if you own property at the time of death, it forms part of your estate and is subject to Spanish inheritance taxes (impuesto de sucesiones). However, if the property has never been properly registered (due to lack of LPO), your heirs face a complex situation where they must pursue the LPO and registration years later, during an already difficult time. The LPO, therefore, is essential for clear estate planning and transmission of assets.

sections.title: Timeline: When Is the LPO Obtained?

subsections.heading: Expected Months After Completion
subsections.content: In a typical scenario, the LPO application is submitted immediately upon construction completion, and the license is issued within 1–4 months. For a straightforward residential building without complex systems or environmental issues, 1–2 months is common. For larger or more complex developments (large residential complexes, mixed-use buildings, properties with special requirements), 3–4 months is reasonable. The timeline starts only after the building is substantially complete—all permanent structures, utilities, and safety systems are in place and functional. Cosmetic finishing (painting, flooring, landscaping) may still be ongoing, but the core building must be done. In rare cases, if the developer identifies deficiencies during the final inspection, remedial work adds 2–8 weeks. The developer should inform you of any such issues and revised timelines. Builders who are deliberately opaque about the LPO timeline are raising a red flag.

subsections.heading: What Your Contract Should Specify
subsections.content: Your purchase contract should include explicit timelines and conditions regarding the LPO: (1) 'The developer will apply for the LPO within 15 days of substantial completion' (you define what substantial completion means—all permanent structures, utilities, safety systems operational). (2) 'The LPO will be obtained within 6 months of the application date, or the developer will extend your payment deadline and offer a reduction in price for each month the LPO is delayed beyond 6 months.' (3) 'The developer will provide you with monthly written updates on the LPO status if the process extends beyond 3 months.' (4) 'The buyer will not make the final payment and will not take possession until the LPO is obtained and the deed is registered at the Property Registry.' (5) 'If the LPO is not obtained within 12 months of construction completion, the buyer has the right to cancel the contract and receive a full refund plus interest.' These provisions are standard in well-drafted contracts with reputable developers. If the developer resists these terms, this is a warning sign about their commitment to legal compliance.

subsections.heading: Monitoring Progress: Your Role
subsections.content: Do not passively wait for the developer to deliver the LPO. Starting 3–4 months after construction completion, begin requesting written status updates from the developer and their project manager. Ask specifically: 'Have you submitted the LPO application? If yes, what is the application reference number? If no, when will you submit?' Request to see a copy of the submitted application. Once submitted, ask: 'What is the expected approval date? Have there been any requests for additional information or remedial work?' Your lawyer can also independently contact the town hall to inquire about the application status (this is typically public information, though not all municipalities readily share it). If the developer becomes evasive or delays responding, or if the town hall indicates the application was not submitted, escalate this immediately with your lawyer. Consider withholding an additional payment (beyond what is held pending LPO) if progress stalls. The developer must know you are monitoring this actively; passive buyers are often deprioritized.

sections.title: What Happens If the LPO Is Delayed

subsections.heading: Short Delays (1–3 Months)
subsections.content: Minor delays in LPO issuance are common and usually not problematic if the developer is actively pursuing approval. Administrative backlogs, slow municipal inspectors, or minor remedial work can push timelines by 1–3 months beyond initial expectations. If you are informed of these delays in advance and the developer provides a realistic revised timeline, this is manageable. However, the developer should also offer a gesture of goodwill—such as paying your utilities for the delayed months, offering a modest price reduction, or covering your temporary accommodation costs if you are displaced by the delay. A developer who simply delays without explanation or compensation is disrespecting your interests.

subsections.heading: Significant Delays (4–12 Months)
subsections.content: Delays exceeding 4 months are concerning and suggest either the developer is not actively pursuing the LPO, or there are underlying compliance issues the municipality is flagging. After 4 months, your lawyer should contact the town hall to inquire about specific issues. Common reasons for significant delays include: (1) The building does not meet fire safety codes and requires expensive remediation. (2) The developer did not adequately budget for cesiones (infrastructure contributions) and the municipality is withholding approval until this is resolved. (3) The developer changed aspects of the building during construction that deviate from the building license, and the municipality is requiring modifications or new approvals. (4) Neighboring residents or environmental groups have filed objections with the municipality. (5) The developer is simply slow and disorganized. If delays stretch to 6+ months, you have grounds to demand significant compensation (price reduction, rental accommodation costs, or interest penalty). If delays exceed 12 months and there is no credible path to LPO, you should seriously consider canceling the contract and recovering your investment.

subsections.heading: Extended Delays: Escalation Steps
subsections.content: If the LPO is not obtained within 12 months of construction completion, follow this escalation: (1) Send a formal written demand to the developer, giving them 30 days to either obtain the LPO or provide a credible action plan. (2) If no response, file a complaint with the relevant consumer protection agency (Oficina Municipal de Información al Consumidor). (3) Request your lawyer to file a claim against the developer in the commercial court (Juzgado Mercantil), seeking damages for the delay (lost rental income, temporary housing costs, diminished property value, emotional distress). (4) If the developer is insolvent or nonresponsive, work with other affected buyers to pursue collective legal action or media attention. On the Costa Blanca, developers who have failed to obtain LPOs for dozens of units have occasionally faced public campaigns that pressure municipalities to take enforcement action. These situations are uncomfortable but sometimes necessary when developers prove unreliable.

subsections.heading: Connecting Utilities Without LPO: Dangers
subsections.content: Some buyers, frustrated by delays, allow builders to connect water and electricity informally without awaiting the LPO. This is unwise. Informal connections are technically illegal and can be disconnected by utility companies if discovered. Additionally, you have no official supply contract, no formal billing, and no regulatory recourse if there are supply problems. Furthermore, banks and insurers view properties with informal utilities as incomplete or problematic and may decline final mortgage disbursement or coverage. Some developers explicitly state 'you can use the property informally while we obtain the LPO,' creating a false sense of ownership. Resist this. Waiting an additional 2–4 months for formal utilities is far preferable to years of uncertainty with informal connections. A property properly completed, with LPO obtained and utilities formally connected, is infinitely more valuable and secure than one occupied informally.

sections.title: Bank Guarantee Implications and Final Payment Protection

subsections.heading: How Banks View LPO Status
subsections.content: When you obtain a mortgage for an off-plan property, the bank conducts its own verification of the project's legal status and timeline to LPO. The bank's decision to disburse funds is partly based on confidence that the LPO will be obtained. Some banks require a bank guarantee (aval bancario) from the developer—a commitment that the bank will freeze or recover funds if the developer does not deliver the LPO within a defined period. These bank guarantees are valuable; they provide a financial backstop if the developer defaults. Other banks do not require bank guarantees but instead stage disbursement in tranches, holding a final percentage (often 10–15%) until the LPO and deed registration are confirmed. If your lender employs bank guarantees, ensure the guarantee explicitly covers failure to obtain the LPO and specifies what recourse you have if it is not obtained. If your lender uses tranched disbursement, confirm the exact conditions for the final tranche: does it require only the LPO, or both the LPO and Property Registry registration? The latter is stronger; the former leaves a gap between LPO issuance and deed registration.

subsections.heading: Holdback Amounts and Escrow Protection
subsections.content: Your purchase contract should specify that a percentage of the total price (typically 5–10%) is held in escrow (cuenta bloqueada) until the LPO is obtained and the deed is registered. This holdback is managed by a neutral third party (often a notary or specialized escrow company) and is released to the developer only upon proof that both conditions are met. A holdback of 5–10% is usually sufficient to incentivize the developer to obtain the LPO promptly; developers are highly motivated to receive final payment. If the developer proposes a contract without a holdback (asking for 100% payment before LPO is ready), this is a major red flag. Legitimate developers accept holdback provisions because they expect to meet timelines. Those resisting holdbacks are signaling either cash flow problems or lack of commitment to regulatory compliance.

subsections.heading: What to Do If the Developer Goes Bankrupt Before LPO
subsections.content: If the developer becomes insolvent and abandons the project before the LPO is obtained, your situation is serious but not hopeless. The property still physically exists, and another builder or contractor can be engaged to complete any remaining work and apply for the LPO. However, this process is complex and costly. Your funds held in escrow can potentially be used to pay for completion work, or you may have a claim against the developer's bankruptcy estate. Consultation with an insolvency lawyer is essential. To protect against this scenario, verify before purchasing that the developer has a solid financial track record, adequate capitalization, and no history of bankruptcy. On the Costa Blanca, established developers like large national companies have lower insolvency risk than smaller local builders. Smaller builders are not inherently untrustworthy, but they warrant greater scrutiny into their financial health.

sections.title: Due Diligence Before Signing: LPO Verification Steps

subsections.heading: Requesting Historical Data on Previous Projects
subsections.content: Before committing to an off-plan purchase, research the developer's track record on LPO timelines for previous projects. Contact previous buyers from completed projects and ask: 'How long did it take to obtain the LPO? Did you experience delays? Were delays explained and compensated?' Request the developer to provide reference properties where you can view the completed project and speak to residents. A developer consistently obtaining LPOs within 3–4 months of completion is demonstrating competence and reliability. A developer with a history of 8–12 month delays or unresolved LPO issues should be approached with extreme caution. On the Costa Blanca, the development community is relatively tightly knit; established agents, notaries, and lawyers usually know which developers have reputations for timely LPO delivery and which have problems. Leverage these connections to gather intelligence.

subsections.heading: Understanding the Inspection Process
subsections.content: Familiarize yourself with what the final municipal inspection entails. The inspector verifies: structural integrity, all utilities are functional and safe, fire safety systems are installed and operational, accessibility requirements are met, environmental conditions are satisfactory, and the building conforms to the building license specifications. If you are technically inclined or have construction knowledge, you can sometimes request to attend the final inspection as an observer (some municipalities permit this, others do not). This gives you visibility into what the municipality is checking and whether any deficiencies are identified. Your lawyer or a technical consultant can also review the final inspection report once it is completed and identify any deficiencies that might delay the LPO.

subsections.heading: Including LPO Conditions in Your Contract
subsections.content: Work with your lawyer to draft a purchase contract that explicitly addresses the LPO. Key contract provisions should include: (1) A clear definition of substantial completion triggering the 6-month LPO timeline. (2) Monthly reporting requirements if the LPO process exceeds 3 months. (3) The holdback amount (5–10%) and the conditions for its release (LPO obtained and deed registered). (4) Price reduction provisions if the LPO is not obtained within 6, 9, or 12 months. (5) The buyer's right to cancel and recover all funds if the LPO is not obtained within 18 months. (6) The developer's obligation to pay for your temporary accommodation if you cannot occupy until the LPO is obtained (if you are relocating from abroad). (7) A representation that the developer will pursue the LPO diligently and will not delay for financial reasons. These provisions are standard in well-drafted contracts and should not be controversial.

content.conclusion: The first occupation license (licencia de primera ocupación) is the final critical hurdle in transforming your off-plan purchase into a legally complete, occupiable property. Without it, you cannot register your deed, connect utilities, obtain insurance, or secure final mortgage funds. For off-plan buyers on the Costa Blanca—whether purchasing in Torrevieja, Orihuela Costa, Javea, or Benidorm—understanding the LPO and its implications is as important as understanding the initial purchase contract. The key takeaway is this: never make your final payment until the LPO is obtained and your deed is registered at the Property Registry. This is your leverage to ensure the developer prioritizes obtaining the LPO promptly. Monitor progress actively, request regular updates, and escalate immediately if delays exceed 3 months. A well-drafted contract with explicit LPO timelines and holdback provisions protects you and incentivizes the developer to perform. Take these steps, and you will avoid the nightmare scenarios that have affected some buyers who failed to insist on proper legal procedures. Your new home on the Costa Blanca should be not only beautiful but also legally secure from the moment you receive your keys.
